intro: Sida cruziana, commonly known as the Brazilian mallow, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems, broad ovate leaves, and showy yellow flowers that bloom in clusters. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates and is often found in disturbed soils. Sida cruziana is also valued for its use in traditional medicine and as a source of fiber.
